form.longName: PhenX PX180502 - Emotional State Child Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: The Positive Affect and Negative Affect Scheduleâ€”Child Form (PANAS-C) is a 30-item self-report questionnaire used to measure the respondent's emotions during the past few weeks. The items are grouped into the subscales indicated in the title of the protocol: positive affect and negative affect. The respondent is asked to read several words which describe feelings and emotions and enter a number that corresponds to the value on a scale. The 5-item scale ranges from "not much or not at all," with a value of 1, to "a lot," with a value of 5.

headerInstruction.text: Feelings and Emotions (PANASC) This scale consists of a number of words that describe different feelings and emotions. Read each item and choose the appropriate answer next to that word. Indicate how much you have felt this way during the ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: PANASC SCORING SHEET Instructions: Record the child or adolescent's rating for each item in the appropriate blank. Ratings are from 1 to 5. To obtain the score for the positive affect (PA) scale, add the raw scores for the 12 items that compose the PA scale. Similarly, adding the raw scores for the 15 items that compose the negative affect (NA) scale results in the score for the NA scale. PA scale: Interested, excited, happy, strong, energetic, calm, cheerful, active, proud, joyful, delighted and lively. PA total ________NA scale: Sad, frightened, ashamed, upset, nervous, guilty, scared, misearable, jittery, afraid, lonely, mad, disgusted, blue, gloomy. NA total ________(panas_c_scoring_180502)

protocol.preferredDefinition:
The Positive Affect and Negative Affect Scheduleâ€”Child Form (PANAS-C) is a 30-item self-report questionnaire used to measure the respondent's emotions during the past few weeks. The items are grouped into the subscales indicated in the title of the protocol: positive affect and negative affect.
The respondent is asked to read several words which describe feelings and emotions and enter a number that corresponds to the value on a scale. The 5-item scale ranges from "not much or not at all," with a value of 1, to "a lot," with a value of 5.

form.longName: PhenX PX180601 - General Selfefficacy Adult Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: This is a 10-item self-administered set of questions used to assess self-efficacy.

question.questionText: I can always manage to solve difficult problems if I try hard enough. (can_solve_difficult_problems)
If someone opposes me, I can find the means and ways to get what I want. (can_get_what_i_want)
It is easy for me to stick to my aims and accomplish my goals. (easy_to_accomplish_my_goals)
I am confident that I could deal efficiently with unexpected events. (deal_efficiently_with_unexpected_events)
Thanks to my resourcefulness, I know how to handle unforeseen situations. (handle_unforeseen_situations)
I can solve most problems if I invest the necessary effort. (can_solve_most_problems)
I can remain calm when facing difficulties because I can rely on my coping abilities. (can_remain_calm)
When I am confronted with a problem, I can usually find several solutions. (can_usually_find_several_solutions)
If I am in trouble, I can usually think of a solution. (can_usually_think_of_solution)
I can usually handle whatever comes my way. (handle_whatever_comes)
Scoring: Responses are made on a 4point scale. Sum up the responses to all 10 items to yield the final composite score with a range from 10 to 40. Do not recode any of the responses (scoring_180601)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This is a 10-item self-administered set of questions used to assess self-efficacy.

form.longName: PhenX PX180602 - General Selfefficacy Child Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: The Self-Efficacy Questionnaire for Children (SEQ-C) includes three 8-item scales that measure academic, social, and emotional self-efficacy. The academic self-efficacy scale includes questions about the person's perception of achieving academic goals. The social self-efficacy scale addresses social challenges and the emotional self-efficacy scale includes questions about coping with unpleasant problems or events.

question.questionText: The answers are coded as: (1) Not at all, (2), (3), (4), (5) Very well (the_answers_are_coded_as_1)
1. How well can you get teachers to help you when you get stuck on schoolwork? (can_get_teachers_to_help)
2. How well can you express your opinions when other classmates disagree with you? (express_opinions)
3. How well do you succeed in cheering yourself up when an unpleasant event has happened? (cheering_self_up)
4. How well can you study when there are other interesting things to do? (how_well_can_study)
5. How well do you succeed in becoming calm again when you are very scared? (become_calm_again_when_scared)
6. How well can you become friends with other children? (become_friends_with_other_children)
7. How well can you study a chapter for a test? (study_a_chapter_for_test)
8. How well can you have a chat with an unfamiliar person? (chat_with_unfamiliar_person)
9. How well can you prevent becoming nervous? (prevent_becoming_nervous)
10. How well do you succeed in finishing all your homework every day? (finish_all_homework_every_day)
11. How well can you work in harmony with your classmates? (harmony_with_your_classmates)
12. How well can you control your feelings? (control_your_feelings)
13. How well can you pay attention during every class? (pay_attention_during_every_class)
14. How well can you tell other children that they are doing something that you don't like? (tell_other_children)
15. How well can you give yourself a pep talk when you feel low? (give_self_pep_talk)
16. How well do you succeed in understanding all subjects in school? (understand_all_subjects_in_school)
17. How well can you tell a funny event to a group of children? (tell_a_funny_event)
18. How well can you tell a friend that you don't feel well? (tell_friend_dont_feel_well)
19. How well do you succeed in satisfying your parents with your schoolwork? (satisfy_parents_with_schoolwork)
20. How well do you succeed in staying friends with other children? (stay_friends)
21. How well do you succeed in suppressing unpleasant thoughts? (suppress_unpleasant_thoughts)
22. How well do you succeed in passing a test? (pass_test)
23. How well do you succeed in preventing quarrels with other children? (prevent_quarrels_with_other_children)
24. How well do you succeed in not worrying about things that might happen? (worry_things_might_happen)

A total selfefficacy score can be obtained by summing across all items. Items 1, 4, 7, 10, 13, 16, 19, and 22 = Academic selfefficacy Items 2, 6, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20, and 23 = Social selfefficacy Items 3, 5, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, and 24 = Emotional selfefficacy Note: Three items of this questionnaire were taken from Bandura et al. (1999). (scoring_180602)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Self-Efficacy Questionnaire for Children (SEQ-C) includes three 8-item scales that measure academic, social, and emotional self-efficacy. The academic self-efficacy scale includes questions about the person's perception of achieving academic goals. The social self-efficacy scale addresses social challenges and the emotional self-efficacy scale includes questions about coping with unpleasant problems or events.

form.longName: PhenX PX180701 - Perceived Social Support Conflict
form.preferredDefinition: The respondent completes three groups of questions about interactions with spouse/partner, family, and friends. Each group includes social support questions about how much they care about you, how much they understand the way you feel, if you can rely on them, and if you can talk to them about your worries. Each group also includes social conflict questions such as if the family members or friends make too many demands on you, criticize you, let you down when you are counting on them, or get on your nerves.

headerInstruction.text: The next several questions are about your spouse/partner. Please choose the appropriate answer for each item. Answer how much for each of these items. A lot, Some, A little, Not at all.

question.questionText: 1a. How much does your spouse or partner really care about you? (spouse_really_care_about_you)
1b. How much does he or she understand the way you feel about things? (spouse_understand_way_you_feel)
1c. How much does he or she appreciate you? (spouse_appreciate_you)
1d. How much can you rely on him or her for help if you have a serious problem? (rely_on_spouse)
1e. How much can you open up to him or her if you need to talk about your worries? (open_up_to_spouse)
1f. How much can you relax and be yourself around him or her? (relax_around_spouse)
Answer how often for each of these items. Often, Sometimes, Rarely, Never (answer_spouse)
1g. How often does your spouse or partner make too many demands on you? (spouse_make_too_many_demands)
1h. How often does he or she make you feel tense? (spouse_make_you_feel_tense)
1i. How often does he or she argue with you? (spouse_argue_with_you)
1j. How often does he or she criticize you? (spouse_criticize_you)
1k. How often does he or she let you down when you are counting on him or her? (spouse_let_you_down)
1l. How often does he or she get on your nerves? (spouse_get_on_your_nerves)

Scoring: next several questions are about your family. Please circle the appropriate number for each item. Answer how much for each of these items. A lot, Some, A little, Not at all. (instructions_family)
2a. Not including your spouse or partner, how much do members of your family really care about you? (family_really_care_about_you)
2b. How much do they understand the way you feel about things? (family_understand_way_you_feel)
2c. How much can you rely on them for help if you have a serious problem? (rely_on_family_for_help)
2d. How much can you open up to them if you need to talk about your worries? (open_up_to_family)
2e. How much do you really care about the members of your family, not including your partner or spouse? (really_care_about_family)
2f. How much do you understand the way they feel about things? (you_understand_family)
Answer how often for each of these items. Often, Sometimes, Rarely, Never. (instructions_how_often_fam)
2g. Not including your spouse or partner, how often do members of your family make too many demands on you? (family_make_demands)
2h. How often do they criticize you? (family_criticize_you)
2i. How often do they let you down when you are counting on them? (family_let_you_down)
2j. How often do they get on your nerves? (family_get_on_your_nerves)

The next several questions are about your friends. Please circle the appropriate number for each item. Answer how much for each of these items. A lot, Some, A little, Not at all (instructions_friends)
3a. How much do your friends really care about you? (friends_really_care_about_you)
3b. How much do they understand the way you feel about things? (friends_understand_way_you_feel)
3c. How much can you rely on them for help if you have a serious problem? (rely_on_friends_for_help)
3d. How much can you open up to them if you need to talk about your worries? (open_up_to_friends)
Answer how often for each of these items. Often, Sometimes, Rarely, Never (answer_how_often_for_each)
3e. How often do your friends make too many demands on you? (friends_make_too_many_demands)
3f. How often do they criticize you? (friends_criticize_you)
3g. How often do they let you down when you are counting on them? (friends_let_you_down)
3h. How often do they get on your nerves? (friends_get_on_your_nerves)

Scaling: Scales are constructed by calculating the mean of the values of the items in each scale. Determine the mean of each positive and negative scale separately, for example, calculate the mean of the spouse/partner support scale (items 1a. through 1f.) separately from the spouse/partner strain scale (items 1g. through 1l.). Items are reversecoded so that high scores reflect higher standing in the scale. Missing Values: The scales are computed for cases that have valid values for at least one item on the particular scale. Scores are not calculated for cases with no valid item on the scales, and coded as "8" for "NOT CALCULATED (Due to missing data)." (scaling_scales_1807001)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The respondent completes three groups of questions about interactions with spouse/partner, family, and friends. Each group includes social support questions about how much they care about you, how much they understand the way you feel, if you can rely on them, and if you can talk to them about your worries. Each group also includes social conflict questions such as if the family members or friends make too many demands on you, criticize you, let you down when you are counting on them, or get on your nerves.

form.preferredDefinition: This 10-item self-administered scale is used to measure an individual's level of perceived stress in the past month. As a result, it measures only current (not chronic) levels of perceived stress.

question.questionText: In the last month, how often have you been upset because of something that happened unexpectedly? (upset_because_of_unexpected)
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life? (unable_to_control_important_things)
In the last month, how often have you felt nervous and "stressed"? (felt_nervous_and_stressed)
In the last month, how often have you felt confident about your ability to handle your personal problems? (felt_confident_to_handle_problems)
In the last month, how often have you felt that things were going your way? (felt_things_going_your_way)
In the last month, how often have you found that you could not cope with all the things that you had to do? (could_not_cope_with_allthings)
In the last month, how often have you been able to control irritations in your life? (able_to_control_irritations)
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were on top of things? (felt_on_top_of_things)
In the last month, how often have you been angered because of things that were outside of your control? (angered_by_things_outside_control)
In the last month, how often have you felt difficulties were piling up so high that you could not overcome them? (difficulties_piling_up)

The Perceived Stress Scale includes 10 questions about the person's feelings and thoughts during the past month. The response options for each feeling or thought indicate the frequency with which it occurred: 0 = Never 1 = Almost Never 2 = Sometimes 3 = Fairly Often 4 = Very Often. Scoring instructions are available on the Carnegie Mellon website. http://www.cmu.edu/commoncoldproject/measuresbystudy/psychologicalandsocialconstructs/stressmeasures/perceivedstress.html (scale_scoring_180801)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This 10-item self-administered scale is used to measure an individual's level of perceived stress in the past month. As a result, it measures only current (not chronic) levels of perceived stress.

form.preferredDefinition: The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale is a 10-item scale used to evaluate a person's general self-worth, with 5 positive statements and 5 negative statements about a person's sense of self-respect and value. It is commonly scored as a 4-point Likert scale, reversing the negative items and combining all 10 items into a single index of global self-esteem. The scale includes values of 1 (strongly agree), 2 (agree), 3 (disagree), and 4 (strongly disagree).

headerInstruction.text: Rosenberg SelfEsteem Scale BELOW IS A LIST OF STATEMENTS DEALING WITH YOUR GENERAL FEELINGS ABOUT YOURSELF

question.questionText: 1. I feel that I'm a person of worth, at least on an equal plane with others. (person_of_worth)
2. I feel that I have a number of good qualities. (number_of_good_qualities)
3. All in all, I am inclined to feel that I am a failure. (inclined_to_feel_a_failure)
4. I am able to do things as well as most other people. (do_as_well_as_others)
5. I feel I do not have much to be proud of. (not_much_tobe_proud_of)
6. I take a positive attitude toward myself. (positive_self_attitude)
7. On the whole, I am satisfied with myself. (satisfied_with_myself)
8. I wish I could have more respect for myself. (wish_have_more_self_respect)
9. I certainly feel useless at times. (feel_useless_at_times)
10. At times I think I am no good at all. (times_think_no_good)

To score the items, assign a value to each of the 10 items as follows: For items 1, 2, 4, 6, 7: Strongly Agree=3, Agree=2, Disagree=1, and Strongly Disagree=0. For items 3, 5, 8, 9, 10 (which are reversed in valence, and noted with the asterisks**): Strongly Agree=0, Agree=1, Disagree=2, and Strongly Disagree=3. The scale ranges from 030, with 30 indicating the highest score possible. Other scoring options are possible. For example, you can assign values 14 rather than 03 then scores will range from 1040. Some researchers use 5 or 7point Likert scales, and again, scale ranges would vary based on the addition of "middle" categories of agreement. (scoring_180901)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale is a 10-item scale used to evaluate a person's general self-worth, with 5 positive statements and 5 negative statements about a person's sense of self-respect and value. It is commonly scored as a 4-point Likert scale, reversing the negative items and combining all 10 items into a single index of global self-esteem. The scale includes values of 1 (strongly agree), 2 (agree), 3 (disagree), and 4 (strongly disagree).

form.preferredDefinition: The UCLA Loneliness Scale includes 20 questions used to assess how lonely the respondent feels. Each question begins with the statement "How often do you feel" followed by a positive or negative description of social interactions with others. The respondent is asked to indicate the frequency he/she feels that way (never, rarely, sometimes, always) for each question.

headerInstruction.text: Instructions: The following statements describe how people sometimes feel. For each statement, please indicate how often you feel the way described by writing a number in the space provided. Here is an example: How often do you feel happy? If ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. How often do you feel that you are in tune with the people around you? (in_tune_with_people)
2. How often do you feel that you lack companionship? (lack_companionship)
3. How often do you feel that there is no one you can turn to? (no_one_can_turn_to)
4. How often do you feel alone? (feel_alone)
5. How often do you feel part of a group of friends? (part_of_group_of_friends)
6. How often do you feel that you have a lot in common with the people around you? (lot_in_common_with_people)
7. How often do you feel that you are no longer close to anyone? (no_longer_close_to_anyone)
8. How often do you feel that your interests and ideas are not shared by those around you? (interests_and_ideas_not_shared)
9. How often do you feel outgoing and friendly? (outgoing_and_friendly)
10. How often do you feel close to people? (close_to_people)
11. How often do you feel left out? (left_out)
12. How often do you feel that your relationships with others are not meaningful? (relationships_with_others_not_meaningful)
13. How often do you feel that no one really knows you well? (no_one_knows)
14. How often do you feel isolated from others? (isolated_from_others)
15. How often do you feel you can find companionship when you want it? (companionship_when_you_want_it)
16. How often do you feel that there are people who really understand you? (people_who_really_understand_you)
17. How often do you feel shy? (feel_shy)
18. How often do you feel that people are around you but not with you? (people_around_not_with_you)
19. How often do you feel that there are people you can talk to? (people_you_can_talk_to)
20. How often do you feel that there are people you can turn to? (people_you_can_turn_to)
Scoring: Items 1, 5, 6, 9, 10, 15, 16, 19, and 20 should be reversed. Sum the total of all items. Higher scores indicate greater degrees of loneliness. (scoring_181001)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The UCLA Loneliness Scale includes 20 questions used to assess how lonely the respondent feels. Each question begins with the statement "How often do you feel" followed by a positive or negative description of social interactions with others. The respondent is asked to indicate the frequency he/she feels that way (never, rarely, sometimes, always) for each question.

form.longName: PhenX PX181201 - Crime And Delinquency Adolescent Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: Using a list of 40 criminal and delinquent questions, the respondent indicates if he or she has engaged in each activity, and if so, how many times in the past year.

headerInstruction.text: This instrument deals with your own behavior. Remember that all your answers are confidential. I'll read a series of behaviors to you. Please give me your best estimate of the exact number of times you've done each thing during the last year.

question.questionText: How many times in the last year have you run away from home? (run_away_from_home)
How many times in the last year have you skipped (classes/school) without an excuse? (skipped_classes_school)
How many times in the last year have you been suspended or sent home from school for bad behavior? (suspended_sent_home)
How many times in the last year have you lied about your age to get into some place or to buy something (for example, lying about your age to get into a movie or to buy alcohol)? (lied_about_age)
How many times in the last year have you cheated on school tests? (cheated)
How many times in the last year have you hitchhiked where it was illegal to do so? (hitchhiked)
How many times in the last year have you carried a hidden weapon? (carried_hidden_weapon)
How many times in the last year have you been loud, rowdy, or unruly in a public place so that people complained about it or you got in trouble? (loud_rowdy_unruly)
How many times in the last year have you begged for money or things from strangers? (begged_for_money)
How many times in the last year have you made obscene telephone calls such as calling someone and saying dirty things? (obscene_telephone_calls)
How many times in the last year have you been drunk in a public place? (publicly_drunk)
How many times in the last year have you purposely damaged or destroyed property that did not belong to you (for example, breaking, cutting or marking up something)? (destroyed_property)
How many times in the last year have you purposely set fire to a house, building, car, or other property or tried to do so? (set_fire)

How many times in the last year have you broken city curfew laws (for example, been in a public place including out in the street without a parent or other adult during the curfew period? (broken_city_curfew_laws)
How many times in the last year have you avoided paying for things such as movies, bus or subway rides, and food or computer services? (avoided_paying)
How many times in the last year have you gone into or tried to go into a building to steal something? (steal_from_building)
How many times in the last year have you stolen or tried to steal money or things worth $5 or less? (steal_5dollars)
How many times in the last year have you stolen or tried to steal money or things worth between $5 and $50? (steal_50_dollars)
How many times in the last year have you stolen or tried to steal money or things worth more than $50 but less than $100? (steal_100_dollars)
How many times in the last year have you stolen or tried to steal money or things worth $100 or more? (steal_morethan_100_dollars)
How many times in the last year have you taken something from a store without paying for it (including events you have already told me about)? (shoplift)
How many times in the last year have you snatched someone's purse or wallet or picked someone's pocket? (stolen_purse_wallet)
How many times in the last year have you taken something from a car that did not belong to you? (steal_from_car)
How many times in the last year have you knowingly bought, sold or held stolen goods or tried to do any of these things? (stolen_goods)
How many times in the last year have you gone joyriding (that is, taken a motor vehicle such as a car or motorcycle for a ride or drive without the owner's permission)? (joyriding)
How many times in the last year have you stolen or tried to steal a motor vehicle such as a car or motorcycle? (steal_car)
How many times in the last year have you used checks illegally or used a slug or fake money to pay for something (including intentional overdrafts)? (fake_money)
How many times in the last year have you used or tried to use a credit or bank cards without the owner's permission? (bank_cards)
How many times in the last year have you tried to cheat someone by selling them something that was worthless or not what you said it was? (cheat_someone)
How many times in the last year have you attacked someone with a weapon or with the idea of seriously hurting or killing them? (attacked_someone)
How many times in the last year have you hit someone with the idea of hurting them (other than the events just mentioned)? (hit_someone)
How many times in the last year have you used a weapon, force, or strongarm methods to get money or things from people? (strongarm_money)
How many times in the last year have you thrown objects such as rocks or bottles at people (other than events you have already mentioned)? (thrown_objects)
How many times in the last year have you been involved in gang fights? (gang_fights)
How many times in the last year have you been paid for having sexual relations with someone? (paid_for_sex)
How many times in the last year have you physically hurt or threatened to hurt someone to get them to have sex with you? (forced_sex)
How many times in the last year have you had or tried to have sexual relations with someone against their will (other than events you just mentioned)? (other_forced_sex)
How many times in the last year have you sold marijuana or hashish ('pot,' 'grass,' 'hash')? (sold_marijuana)
How many times in the last year have you sold hard drugs such as heroin, cocaine, and LSD (total freq. of all hard drug sales, not limited to these three drugs)? (sold_hard_drugs)
Have you done anything else in the past year that could have gotten you in trouble with the police? (trouble_with_police)
What kind of things did you do? (trouble_with_police_specify_1)
How many times in the past year? (trouble_with_police_frequency_1)
What kind of things did you do? (trouble_with_police_specify_2)
How many times in the past year? (trouble_with_police_frequency_2)
What kind of things did you do? (trouble_with_police_specify_3)
How many times in the past year? (trouble_with_police_frequency_3)
What kind of things did you do? (trouble_with_police_specify_4)
How many times in the past year? (trouble_with_police_frequency_4)
What kind of things did you do? (trouble_with_police_specify_5)
How many times in the past year? (trouble_with_police_frequency_5)

Typically researchers use this information to capture which criminal and delinquent activities occurred and the prevalence during the last year. Scoring can take the form of counting up the number of items endorsed or by calculating the sum of the item frequencies, where the nonendorsed items are scored "0". In addition, types of antisocial and criminal behaviors can be assessed (alcohol and drug use, minor delinquency, serious delinquency, violence, etc.). A Guttman scale may be used to classify the more serious or violent offenses (see Loeber et al., 1998). Researchers should consult with the original sources and later publications for examples of scoring techniques. If a summary delinquency scale is being prepared the Psychosocial Working Group recommends that items that are not against the law be removed from the scale (e.g., skipped school, cheated on school tests, suspended for bad behavior). In addition, items that overlap, such as stealing something worth $5 to $50 and taking something from the store without paying (shoplifting) should not count as two endorsed items, only one. (scoring181201)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Using a list of 40 criminal and delinquent questions, the respondent indicates if he or she has engaged in each activity, and if so, how many times in the past year.

form.longName: PhenX PX181202 - Crime And Delinquency Adult Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: Using a list of 48 criminal and delinquent activities, the respondent indicates if he or she has engaged in each activity, and if so, how many times in the past year.

headerInstruction.text: I am going to describe some behaviors to you. Try to recall how many times you have done this thing during the last year. Coding: "HOW MANY TIMES THIS YEAR....": 000 = respondent did not engage in behavior in the past year 001 700 = number ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: How many times in the last year did you run away from your home and stay away overnight? (pxt181202_run_away_from_home)
How many times in the last year did you carry a hidden weapon? (carry_hidden_weapon)
How many times in the last year were you loud, rowdy, or unruly in a public place so that people complained about it or you got into trouble? (pxt181202_loud_rowdy_unruly)
How many times in the last year did you purposely damage or destroy property that did not belong to you? (damaged_destroyed_property)
How many times in the last year did you purposely set fire to a house, building, car or other property or try to do so? (purposely_set_fire)
How many times in the last year did you break into, or try to break into a building, to steal something? (broke_into_building)
How many times in the last year did you steal, or try to steal, money or things worth $5 or less? (stolen_5_or_less)
How many times in the last year did you steal, or try to steal, money or things worth between $5 and $100? (stolen_5_100)
How many times in the last year did you steal, or try to steal, money or things worth between $100 and $500? (stolen_100_500)
How many times in the last year did you steal, or try to steal, money or things worth over $500? (stolen_over_500)
How many times in the last year have you taken something from a store without paying for it? (including events you have already told me about). (pxt181202_shoplift)
How many times in the last year have you snatched someone's purse or wallet, or picked someone's pocket? (snatched_purse_or_wallet)
How many times in the last year have you taken something from a car that did not belong to you? (taken_from_car)
How many times in the last year have you knowingly bought, sold, or held stolen goods or tried to do any of these things? (pxt181202_stolen_goods)

How many times in the last year have you converted a vehicle, that is, taken a motor vehicle such as a car or motorcycle for a ride or drive without the owner's permission, when you didn't mean to keep or sell it? (converted_a_vehicle)
How many times in the last year have you stolen, or tried to steal, a motor vehicle such as a car or motorcycle to keep or sell? (stolenmotor_vehicle)
How many times in the last year have you used worthless checks or fake money to pay for something? (worthless_checks)
How many times in the last year have you used, or tried to use, credit or bank cards for checks without the owner's permission? (credit_or_bank_cards)
How many times in the last year have you tried to cheat someone by selling them something that was worthless, or not what you said it was? (tried_to_cheat_someone)
How many times in the last year have you been so angry with a child that you attacked them with a weapon, or with the idea of seriously hurting them? (attacked_child)
How many times in the last year have you been so angry with a child that you hit them (other than the events you just told me about)? (attacked_child_other)
How many times in the last year have you attacked an adult with a weapon or with the idea of seriously hurting or killing them? (Don't include partners) (attacked_adult_with_weapon)
How many times in the last year have you hit an adult with the idea of hurting them? (Don't include partners) (hit_an_adult)
How many times in the last year have you used a weapon, force or strong arm methods to rob a person, shop, bank, or other business? (strong_arm_methods)
How many times in the last year have you been involved in a gang fight? (gang_fight)

How many times in the last year have you committed a serious driving offense, such as driving while drunk, driving recklessly, or speeding 50 km per hour over the posted speed limit (For example, 150 km/hr [90 mph] in a 100 km/hr [60 mph] zone)? (serious_driving_offense)

How many times in the last year have you embezzled money: that means used money entrusted to your care for some purpose not intended? (examples: charity collections, office accounts) (embezzled_money)
How many times in the last year have you lied about your age? (lied_about_your_age)
How many times in the last year have you begged for money or things from strangers? (pxt181202_begged_for_money)
How many times in the last year have you made obscene telephone calls, such as calling someone and saying rude things? (made_obscene_telephone_calls)
How many times in the last year have you been drunk in a public place? (been_drunk_in_public)
How many times in the last year have you avoided paying for things such as movies, bus or subway rides, food or computer services? (pxt181202_avoided_paying)
How many times in the last year did you give false information on a tax form, an insurance claim, or on applications for a loan or bank account? (gave_false_information)
How many times in the last year did you use a false name or alias so you couldn't be identified? (used_a_false_name)
How many times in the last year did you move away from a flat or house without paying the final bills or rent? (moved_without_paying)
How many times in the last year have you made illegal copies of computer software or video files? (made_illegal_copies)
How many times in the last year did you buy something on credit and then never made the payments? (never_made_the_payments)

How many times in the last year did you Interfere with the work of the law by trying to get away from police, by hiding someone that the police were looking for, or by telling a lie to a police officer or judge? (interfered_with_police)
How many times in the last year have you driven a vehicle when you did not have a driver's license or after your license had been suspended or disqualified? (suspended_license)
How many times in the last year have you sold marijuana or hashish? (sold_marijuana_or_hashish)
How many times in the last year have you sold hard drugs, such as heroin, cocaine or LSD? (pxt181202_sold_hard_drugs)
How many times in the last year have you used marijuana? (used_marijuana)
How many times in the last year have you used a harder drug, such as heroin, cocaine or LSD? (used_a_harder_drug)
How many times in the last year have you paid someone to have sex with you? (paid_someone_for_sex)
How many times in the last year have you been paid, or received other favors for having sex with someone? (paid_for_having_sex)
How many times in the last year did you threaten or hurt someone to get them to have sex with you? (force_sex)

How many times in the last year have you contributed to the delinquency of a person under age 17? That is, you helped them to run away, gave them alcohol or drugs, or had sex with them. (contributed_to_delinquency)

How many times in the last year have you failed to obey the courts? That is, failed to answer summons by bailiff failed to show up for periodic detention broke conditions of parole failed to pay a fine escaped or tried to escape prison or jail or failed to pay child support? (failed_to_obey_courts)

Typically researchers use this information to capture which criminal and delinquent activities occurred and the prevalence during the last year. Scoring can take the form of counting up the number of items endorsed or by calculating the sum of the item frequencies, where the nonendorsed items are scored "0". In addition, types of antisocial and criminal behaviors can be assessed (alcohol and drug use, minor delinquency, serious delinquency, violence, etc.). A Guttman scale may be used to classify the more serious or violent offenses (see Loeber et al., 1998). Researchers should consult with the original sources and other publication for examples of scoring techniques. If a summary delinquency scale is being prepared, the Psychosocial Working Group recommends that items that are not against the law be removed from the scale (e.g., ran away, lied about age [unless some illegal context is specified], provided false name or alias [unless some illegal context is specified]). In addition, items that overlap, such as stealing something worth $5 to $100 and taking something from the store without paying (shoplifting) should not count as two endorsed items, only one. (socring181202)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Using a list of 48 criminal and delinquent activities, the respondent indicates if he or she has engaged in each activity, and if so, how many times in the past year.

form.preferredDefinition: The chronic stress scale includes a list of 51 items about common life conditions and situations (e.g., financial issues, work, love and marriage, family and children, social life). The interviewer reads each item aloud and asks the respondent to reply with not true (0), somewhat true (1), or very true (2).

headerInstruction.text: Below are some situations that sometimes come up in people's lives. Please choose if these things are: not true somewhat true very true for you at this time.

question.questionText: 1. You're trying to take on too many things at once. (too_many_things_at_once)
2. There is too much pressure on you to be like other people. (pressure_to_be_like_others)
3. Too much is expected of you by others. (too_much_expected_by_others)
4. You don't have enough money to buy the things you or your kids need. (not_enough_money_for_needs)
5. You have a longterm debt or loan. (longterm_debt_or_loan)
6. Your rent or mortgage is too much. (rent_mortgage_too_much)
7. You don't have enough money to take vacations. (not_enough_money_for_vacations)
8. You don't have enough money to make a down payment on a home. (not_enough_money_for_downpayment)
9. You have more work to do than most people. (more_work_than_most_people)
10. Your supervisor is always monitoring what you do at work. (supervisor_always_monitoring_you)
11. You want to change jobs or career but don't feel you can. (dont_feel_can_change_job)
12. Your job often leaves you feeling both mentally and physically tired. (job_often_leaves_you_tired)
13. You want to achieve more at work but things get in the way. (want_achieve_more_at_work)
14. You don't get paid enough for what you do. (dont_get_paid_enough)
15. Your work is boring and repetitive. (work_is_boring_and_repetitive)
16. You are looking for a job and can't find the one you want. (cant_find_job_you_want)
17. You have a lot of conflict with your partner. (conflict_with_partner)
18. Your relationship restricts your freedom. (relationship_restricts_your_freedom)
19. Your partner doesn't understand you. (partner_doesnt_understand_you)
20. Your partner expects too much of you. (partner_expects_too_much)
21. You don't get what you deserve out of your relationship. (dont_get_needs_from_relationship)
22. Your partner doesn't show enough affection. (partner_doesnt_show_enough_affection)
23. Your partner is not committed enough to your relationship. (partner_not_committed_enough)
24. Your sexual needs are not fulfilled by this relationship. (sexual_needs_not_fulfilled)
25. Your partner is always threatening to leave or end the relationship. (partner_always_threatening_to_leave)
26. You wonder whether you will ever get married. (wonder_whether_ever_get_married)
27. You find it is too difficult to find someone compatible with you. (difficult_to_find_someone_compatible)
28. You have a lot of conflict with your exspouse. (conflict_with_your_ex)
29. You don't see your children from a former marriage as much as you would like. (dont_see_children_from_marriage)
30. You are alone too much. (alone_too_much)
31. You wish you could have children but you cannot. (wish_you_could_have_children)
32. One of your children seems very unhappy. (one_of_children_unhappy)
33. You feel your children don't listen to you. (children_dont_listen_to_you)
34. A child's behavior is a source of serious concern to you. (childs_behavior_source_of_concern)
35. One or more children do not do well enough at school or work. (children_dont_do_well_enough)
36. Your children don't help around the house. (children_dont_help_around_house)
37. One of your children spends too much time away from the house. (children_spend_toomuch_time_away)
38. You feel like being a housewife is not appreciated. (feel_housewife_not_appreciated)
39. You have to go to social events alone and you don't want to. (go_to_social_events_alone)
40. Your friends are a bad influence. (friends_are_bad_influence)
41. You don't have enough friends. (dont_have_enough_friends)
42. You don't have time for your favorite leisure time activities. (no_time_favorite_leisure_activities)
43. You want to live farther away from your family. (want_tolive_farther_from_family)
44. You would like to move but you cannot. (want_to_move_but_cannot)
45. The place you live is too noisy or too polluted. (place_you_live_noisy_polluted)
46. Your family lives too far away. (family_lives_too_far_away)
47. Someone in your family or a close friend has a longterm illness or handicap. (familyfriend_has_longterm_illnesshandicap)
48. You have a parent, a child, or a spouse or partner who is in very bad health and may die. (family_member_may_die)
49. Someone in your family has an alcohol or drug problem. (family_member_alcoholdrug_problem)
50. A long term health problem prevents you from doing the things you like to do. (health_problem_prevents_activities)
51. You take care of an aging parent almost every day. (take_care_aging_parent)

Scoring: The 51item scale may be broken down into 13 subscales as shown in the table below. For each item, a response of not true = 0, somewhat true = 1, and very true = 2. Calculate the score from each individual subscale. Of the two methods to obtain an overall score, the first is to add up all very trues or very trues and somewhat trues. However, if a person does not have a particular role (e.g., parent), then the question is scored with a zero (see subscale table for universal vs. rolespecific designations). The other method is to code the items as missing if a respondent is not in the role and therefore was not asked these questions, and then take the average of all subscales. The scores cannot simply be added up because the total is confounded by the number of roles the person is in and that is a proxy for social competence, therefore cutting across the point of the scale. (scoring_181301)
scoringtbl181301 (scoringtbl181301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The chronic stress scale includes a list of 51 items about common life conditions and situations (e.g., financial issues, work, love and marriage, family and children, social life). The interviewer reads each item aloud and asks the respondent to reply with not true (0), somewhat true (1), or very true (2).

form.longName: PhenX PX181401 - Exposures To Violence Adult Protocol
form.preferredDefinition: The respondent is asked a comprehensive list of questions about trauma and victimization experiences over his/her lifetime. If the respondent answers "yes" to the first question, the interviewer administers additional follow-up questions about the event. Follow-up questions collect information about the person's age when the event occurred, whether serious injury or death was involved, if there was an intense feeling of fear and helplessness, the frequency of the event, and whether anyone else ever tried to harm the person in the same way. The questions are sensitive and cover subjects such as physical violence, sexual abuse, suicide, and murder.

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever been involved in a natural disaster, such as a tornado, hurricane, flood, or earthquake? (natural_disaster)
How old were you the first time it happened? (natural_disaster_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (natural_disaster_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (natural_disaster_intense_fear)
Was there another time you were involved in a natural disaster, such as a tornado, hurricane, flood, or earthquake? (natural_disaster_other_time)
2. Have you ever been involved in a manmade disaster, such as a fire, train crash, car accident, or building collapse? (manmade_disaster)
How old were you the first time it happened? (manmade_disaster_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (manmade_disaster_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (manmade_disaster_intense_fear)
Was there another time where you were involved in a manmade disaster, such as a fire, train crash, car accident, or building collapse? (manmade_disaster_other_time)
3. Have you ever been involved in direct combat experience in a war? [NOTE: INCLUDE POLICE SHOOTOUTS AND GANG FIGHTS] (combat_experience)
How old were you the first time it happened? (combat_experience_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (combat_experience_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (combat_experience_fear)
Was there another time where you were involved in direct combat experience in a war? [NOTE: INCLUDE POLICE SHOOTOUTS AND GANG FIGHTS] (combat_experience_other_time)
4. Have you ever lived in a war zone? (For example, the Persian Gulf or Bosnia). (lived_warzone)
How old were you the first time it happened? (lived_warzone_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (lived_warzone_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (lived_warzone_intense_fear)
Was there another time that you lived in a war zone? (lived_warzone_other_time)
5. Have you ever had a serious accident at home, at work, or somewhere else? (serious_accident)
How old were you the first time it happened? (serious_accident_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (serious_accident_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (serious_accident_intense_fear)
Was there another time you had a serious accident at home, at work, or somewhere else? (serious_accident_other_time)
6. Have you ever been exposed to dangerous chemicals or radioactivity? (chemicals_radiation)
How old were you the first time it happened? (chemicals_radiation_age)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (chemicals_radiation_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (chemicals_radiation_intense_fear)
Was there another time you were exposed to dangerous chemicals or radioactivity? (chemicals_radiation_other_time)
7. Have you ever been shot at, stabbed, struck, kicked, beaten, punched, slapped around, or otherwise physically harmed? (physically_harmed)
How old were you the first time it happened? (physically_harmed_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (physically_harmed_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (physically_harmed_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (physically_harmed_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (physically_harmed_age_last_time)
Has anyone else ever shot at, stabbed, struck, kicked, beaten, punched, slapped around, or otherwise physically harmed you? (physically_harmed_other_time)
8. Have you ever been threatened with any kind of a weapon, like a knife, gun, baseball bat, frying pan, scissors, stick, rock or bottle? (threatened)
How old were you the first time it happened? (threatened_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (threatened_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (threatened_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (threatened_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (threatened_age_last_happened)
Has anyone else threatened you with any kind of weapon? (threatened_other_times)
9. Has anyone ever threatened you in a facetoface confrontation? (threatened_confrontation)
How old were you the first time it happened? (threatened_confrontation_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (threatened_confrontation_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (threatened_confrontation_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (threatened_confrontation_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (threatened_confrontation_age_last_happened)
Has anyone else threatened you in a facetoface confrontation? (threatened_confrontation_other_times)
10. Have you ever been actually assaulted with any kind of a weapon, like a knife, gun, baseball bat, frying pan, scissors, stick, rock, or bottle? (assaulted_weapon)
How old were you the first time it happened? (assaulted_weapon_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (assaulted_weapon_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (assaulted_weapon_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (assaulted_weapon_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (assaulted_weapon_age_last_happened)
Has anyone else actually assaulted you with any kind of a weapon, like a knife, gun, baseball bat, frying pan, scissors, stick, rock, or bottle? (assaulted_weapon_other_times)

11. When you were a childthat is, when you were in elementary or middle school, before about age 12were you ever struck, kicked, beaten, punched, slapped around, or otherwise physically harmed? (physically_harmed_before12)
How old were you the first time it happened? (physically_harmed_before12_age_firsthappened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (physically_harmed_before12_afraid_mightdie)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (physically_harmed_before12_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (physically_harmed_before12_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (physically_harmed_before12_age_lasthappened)
During your childhoodwere you struck, kicked, beaten, punched, slapped around, or otherwise physically harmed by anyone else? (physically_harmed_before12_other_times)
12. When you were a child that is, when you were in elementary or middle school, before about age 12were you ever physically abused? (physicallyabused_before12)
How old were you the first time it happened? (physicallyabused_before12_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (physicallyabused_before12_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (physicallyabused_before12_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (physicallyabused_before12_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (physicallyabused_before12_age_last_happened)
During your childhoodhas anyone else physically abused you? (physicallyabused_before12_other_times)
13. Has anyonemale or femaleever forced or coerced you to engage in unwanted sexual activity? (forced_sexual_activity)
How old were you the first time it happened? (forced_sexual_activity_age_firsthappened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (forced_sexual_activity_seriousinjury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (forced_sexual_activity_intensefear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (forced_sexual_activity_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (forced_sexual_activity_age_lasthappened)
Has anyone elsemale or femaleever forced or coerced you to engage in unwanted sexual activity? (forced_sexual_activity_other_times)
14. Other than what we just talked about, did anyone, male or female ever attempt tobut not actually force you to engage in unwanted sexual activity? (attempted_sexual_activity)
How old were you the first time it happened? (attempted_sexual_activity_age_firsthappened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (attempted_sexual_activity_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (attempted_sexual_activity_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (attempted_sexual_activity_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (attempted_sexual_activity_age_last_happened)
Has anyone elsemale or female, attempted tobut not actuallyforced you to engage in unwanted sexual activity? (attempted_sexual_activity_other_times)
15. Other than what we just talked about, has anyone ever actually touched private parts of your body or made you touch theirs against your wishes? (private_parts)
How old were you the first time it happened? (private_parts_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (private_parts_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (private_parts_intense_fear)
How many times did this person do this to you? (private_parts_times)
How old were you the last time this person did this to you? (private_parts_age_last_happened)
Has anyone else ever actually touched private parts of your body or made you touch theirs against your wishes? (private_parts_other_times)
16. Have you ever had an immediate family member, romantic partner, or very close friend who was murdered? (knownsomeone_murdered)
How old were you the first time it happened? (knownsomeone_murdered_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (knownsomeone_murdered_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (knownsomeone_murdered_intense_fear)
Was anyone else who was an immediate family member, romantic partner, or very close friend murdered? (knownsomeone_murdered_other_times)
17. Have you ever seen or been present when someone was murdered or seriously injured? (witness_murder)
How old were you the first time it happened? (witness_murder_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (witness_murder_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (witness_murder_intense_fear)
Was there any other time when you saw or were present when someone was murdered or seriously injured? (witness_murder_other_times)
18. Have you ever had an immediate family member, romantic partner, or very close friend commit suicide? (knownsomeone_suicide)
How old were you the first time it happened? (knownsomeone_suicide_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (knownsomeone_suicide_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (knownsomeone_suicide_intense_fear)
Did anyone else who was an immediate family member, romantic partner, or very close friend commit suicide? (knownsomeone_suicide_other_times)
19. Have you ever seen a dead or mutilated body? Other than at a funeral, in the movies or newspaper? (dead_body)
How old were you the first time it happened? (dead_body_age_first_happened)
Were you in danger of death or serious injury? (dead_body_serious_injury)
Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (dead_body_intense_fear)
Was there any other time when you saw a dead or mutilated body? (dead_body_other_times)

27. Has anyone ever stolen something directly from you without the threat or use of force (for example pursesnatching or pickpocket)? (stolen_without_threat)

28. Have you ever been kidnapped or held captive? (kidnapped)

Did you feel intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (kidnapped_intense_fear)

29. Have you ever been stalked by anyone? For example, has anyone ever followed or spied on you? (stalked)

30. Have you ever been in any other situation in which you were in danger of death or serious physical injury, or in which you felt intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (other_situations)
If Yes, please specify: (other_situations_specify)
How old were you the first time it happened? (other_situations_age)
Was there any other situation in which you were in danger of death or serious physical injury, or in which you felt intense fear, helplessness, or horror? (other_situations2)

Scoring: There are several ways to score the instrument, from very simple to more complex. One can simply count the number of events that the person endorsed, the total number of events (that is, if the event happened more than once), or the number of items of different types (general traumas, items 16 physical violence, items 710 physical abuse, items 1112 sexual violence, items 1315 seen family/friend murdered or commit suicide, items 1618 witnessed trauma to someone else, items 1921 crime victimization, items 2227 kidnapped or stalked, items 2829 or anything else, item 30). One can count items that occurred during certain time periods in the person's life (childhood, adolescence, or adulthood) or items that only reached a certain threshold of intensity, based on questions about the person's perception of the event (i.e., Were you afraid that you might die or get hurt really badly?). For certain purposes where less detail is desired, one might omit these followup questions entirely. (scoring_181401)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The respondent is asked a comprehensive list of questions about trauma and victimization experiences over his/her lifetime. If the respondent answers "yes" to the first question, the interviewer administers additional follow-up questions about the event. Follow-up questions collect information about the person's age when the event occurred, whether serious injury or death was involved, if there was an intense feeling of fear and helplessness, the frequency of the event, and whether anyone else ever tried to harm the person in the same way. The questions are sensitive and cover subjects such as physical violence, sexual abuse, suicide, and murder.

form.longName: PhenX PX181402 - Exposures To Violence Child Protocol

If the respondent answers "yes" to the first question, the interviewer administers additional follow-up questions about the event. Follow-up questions collect information about the person's age, when the event occurred, whether serious injury or death was involved, if there was an intense feeling of fear and helplessness, the frequency of the event, and whether anyone else ever tried to harm the person in the same way. The questions are sensitive and cover subjects such as physical violence, sexual abuse, suicide, and murder.

headerInstruction.text: A "yes" or "no" response is all the information we are requesting from the respondent. We do not want to ask them details about what might have been a very painful experience. The question "were you in danger of death or serious physical injur..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. Have you ever been involved in a natural disaster, like a tornado, a hurricane, a flood, or an earthquake? (pxt181402_natural_disaster)

Were you very scared? (natural_disaster_scared)
Were you afraid that you might die or get hurt really badly? (natural_disaster_afraid_might_die)
Did you feel like there was nothing you could do to stop what was happening? (natural_disaster_could_not_stop)
Was there another time you were involved in a natural disaster, like a tornado, hurricane, flood, or earthquake? (pxt181402_natural_disaster_other_time)
2. Have you ever been involved in a manmade disaster, like a fire, a train crash, a car accident, or a building falling down? (pxt181402_manmade_disaster)

30. Have you ever been in any other situation in which you were afraid you might die or get really badly hurt, or when you were very scared or felt like there was nothing you could do to stop what was happening? (pxt181402_other_situations)

Have you ever been in any other situation in which you were afraid you might die or get really badly hurt, or when you were very scared or felt like there was nothing you could do to stop what was happening? SPECIFY (pxt181402_other_situations_specify)
How old were you the first time it happened? (other_situations_age_first_happened)

Was there any other situation in which you were afraid you might die or get really badly hurt, or when you were very scared or felt like there was nothing you could do to stop what was happening? (pxt181402_other_situations2)

There are several ways to score the instrument, from very simple to more complex. One can simply count the number of events that the person endorsed, the total number of events (that is, if the event happened more than once) or the number of items of different types (general traumas, items 16 physical violence, items 710 physical abuse, items 1112 sexual violence, items 1315 seen family/friend murdered or commit suicide, items 1618 witnessed trauma to someone else, items 1921 crime victimization, items 2227 kidnapped or stalked, items 2829 or anything else, item 30). One can count items that occurred during certain time periods in the person's life (childhood, adolescence, or adulthood) or items that only reached a certain threshold of intensity, based on questions about the person's perception of the event (i.e., Were you afraid that you might die or get hurt really badly?). For certain purposes where less detail is desired, one might omit these followup questions entirely. (scoring_0181402)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The respondent is asked a comprehensive list of questions about trauma and victimization experiences over his/her lifetime. If the respondent answers "yes" to the first question, the interviewer administers additional follow-up questions about the event. Follow-up questions collect information about the person's age, when the event occurred, whether serious injury or death was involved, if there was an intense feeling of fear and helplessness, the frequency of the event, and whether anyone else ever tried to harm the person in the same way. The questions are sensitive and cover subjects such as physical violence, sexual abuse, suicide, and murder.
